entry.title: The field "XXXX" does not have a corresponding field in the work area.
entry.content:
Hello.
Activating a report we have several warnings like this:

The field "WERKS" does not have a corresponding field in the work area.
The field "LIFNR" does not have a corresponding field in the work area.

Etc...

But these fields are actually in the work area.

The structure is created like this:

TYPES:
 BEGIN OF tys_table.
        INCLUDE TYPE z_my_estructure.
TYPES:
  menge         TYPE menge_d,
  ktmng         TYPE ktmng,
END OF tys_table,
 tyt_table TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tys_table.

So, its not detecting the fields in the structure in INCLUDE TYPE.

Is there any SAP Note to fix this problem? its annoying to see dozens of messages like this when everything is fine.

Regards.

entry.title: Leverage AI Agents in Enterprise Security
entry.content:
Leveraging AI Agents in Enterprise Security

As the world of cybersecurity evolves rapidly, the scale and sophistication of attacks are also increasing. Malicious actors are becoming smarter, and with the help of AI, the curation of attacks is advancing. Meanwhile, cybersecurity professionals struggle with alert fatigue and resource shortages. Traditional security tools, reliant on static rules and signature-based detection, are struggling to keep up. This has created a critical gap between the speed of attacks and the response capabilities of human security teams. To address this, enterprises require an advanced security platform that can think, learn, adapt, and respond intelligently.

Security Challenges

Large Alert Volumes (CVE)

SIEMs and IDS systems generate thousands of alerts daily, making manual review nearly impossible. Many alerts are noise or false positives. The time to identify and contain a breach averages 277 days, costing organizations millions.[1]

Zero-day Attack Vectors

Zero-day vulnerabilities are unknown security flaws with no available patches. They are dangerous because attackers can exploit them before defenders have any chance to react.

Human Resource Limitations

As environments scale, manual log analysis becomes infeasible. This leads to alert fatigue, causing critical threats to be missed.

Blind Spots

Complex environments often have limited visibility due to network and endpoint blind spots. Attackers exploit these gaps with tactics like zero-day exploits, ransomware, and social engineering.

Delayed Response Time

Even after detecting a threat, organizations may take hours or days to respond‚Äîsignificantly increasing damage.

Current Implementation in HCM

Today‚Äôs processes rely heavily on traditional DevSecOps methods such as SAST, DAST, IDS/IPS, and vulnerability scanning. These tools are rule-based and require extensive manual review.

Security Development & Operations Lifecycle

 

Despite integration across the lifecycle, these tools still need significant manual effort and cross-team communication:

  • SAST & DAST: More than 70% false positives requiring manual review.
  • Security Controls: Manual remediation even for small changes.
  • Secret Scanners: Find sensitive information in code repositories.
  • CI/CD Automation: Pipeline-dependent, rule-based, requires continuous rule maintenance.

HXM SIEM Process

 

  • Policy and Security Requirements: BISO
  • Tooling: SecOps
  • Response: App/Platform Ops

AI Agents: Autonomous Security Analysts

An AI agent in cybersecurity is an autonomous system powered by LLMs, ML, and NLP. It perceives logs, network traffic, and user behavior; analyzes threats; and can take predefined actions‚Äîwithout constant human intervention.

How AI Agents Work

AI agents perform multiple roles and can collaborate with other agents or external tools via APIs.

Example Roles

  • Threat Hunting & Detection: Detect anomalies and zero-day attacks without rule dependency.
  • Threat Analysis & Correlation: Reduce noise by correlating logs across systems.
  • Automated Response & Patching: Quarantine devices, revoke access, or roll back systems.
  • Forensics: Trace attack origins and impacts.
  • Proactive & Predictive Defense: Identify misconfigurations and predicted attack vectors.

AI Agent Development Frameworks

  • LangChain: For multi-step LLM workflows integrating reasoning and tool usage.
  • AutoGen: Microsoft‚Äôs framework for multi-agent collaboration.
  • CrewAI: Role-based multi-agent orchestration framework.

What Gaps Can AI Close?

Advanced Threat Detection

AI agents detect unknown threats using unsupervised learning, closing gaps in rule-based security tools.

Anomaly Detection & Behavior Analysis

Agents establish baseline behavior and flag deviations‚Äîcatching stealthy attacks that evade traditional detection.

Zero-Day Vulnerability Detection

Agents analyze behavior patterns to detect zero-day attacks earlier, giving analysts time to respond.

Real-Time Threat Detection

AI filters large SIEM/IDS data streams and reduces false positives, allowing analysts to focus on high-impact events.

Social Engineering & AI-driven Phishing

Agents analyze email content, sender reputation, and context to detect highly realistic phishing attempts.

Automating Routine Investigations

Agents continuously scan for IOCs and ensure compliance without manual audits.

Incident Response Automation

Once a threat is confirmed, agents execute predefined actions such as blocking IPs or isolating endpoints.

Real-World Use Cases

  • Microsoft Security Copilot: Phishing triage and vulnerability remediation.[2]
  • CrowdStrike Charlotte AI: Doubles detection triage speed and reduces computational load by 50%.[3]
  • 360 Security Agent: Identified and analyzed an APT in 1 minute.[4]
  • Darktrace Antigena: Real-time autonomous device isolation.[5]

AI agent adoption spans:

  • SOAR platforms
  • SOCs
  • Endpoint security
  • Cloud security

Challenges & Responsible Deployment

  • Hallucinations: LLMs may generate incorrect insights.
  • Adversarial Attacks: Agents may be vulnerable to prompt injection or model poisoning.
  • Data Privacy Risks: Continuous monitoring must comply with regulations.
  • Need for Human Oversight: Ethical or critical decisions require human judgment.

Responsible deployment requires red-teaming, runtime guardrails, confidential computing, and human-in-the-loop workflows.

Conclusion

The cybersecurity gap‚Äîdriven by complex threats and limited human capacity‚Äîis one of the biggest challenges of our digital era. AI agents provide unprecedented scale, speed, and intelligence, transforming security from reactive to proactive. With thoughtful governance, AI agents help organizations stay ahead of threats and build a safer digital ecosystem.

References

  1. Multi-AI Agent Security Technology (folio3.ai)
  2. Microsoft Security Copilot (windowsnew.ai)
  3. How AI Agents Improve Cybersecurity (nvidia.com)
  4. 360 AI Agents ‚Äì Tencent
  5. Multi-AI Agent Security Technology (foli3.ai)

entry.title: Re: intercompany stock transfer with consignment
entry.content:
Consignment process will meet your requirement

  • Customer order at Company A: Triggers a consignment STO from Company B to Company A.
  • Goods receipt at Company A: Stock is posted into consignment stock under Company B. No financial posting yet, since ownership is still with Company B.
  • PGI against sales order: When Company A delivers to the end customer, the consignment stock is issued (Consignment Issue). Ownership transfers from Company B to Company A, and billing is triggered.

In short, the standard way is to use Consignment Fill-Up for STO receipt and Consignment Issue at PGI. This ensures inventory is tracked under Company B until consumption, at which point ownership and billing transfer to Company A.

entry.title: Re: BRf+ - OPD Transition Help Condition Determination
entry.content:
Dear @GAK1,

Scalable way (my recommendation/proposal): create a custom ‚ÄûEDI vs Form‚Äù field and use it in OPD

If you have many customers, hard-coding customer numbers in OPD will be painful.
Better: create a small custom field on the customer (BP) for example: Output Channel: EDI / FORM, and expose it to OPD.

Create a custom field on the customer

  1. Open Custom Fields app.
  2. Create a new field, for example:
    • for example, Customer: Sales Area or Business Partner: General (depends where you want to maintain it)
    • Example: Code list with values:
      • EDI
      • FORM
    • Relevant UIs
    • Relevant OData services / CDS views for your docs (Sales / Billing)
    • Business Context:
    • Type: Code list or Checkbox
    • Enable the field in:
  3. VERY IMPORTANT: enable usage for ‚ÄûCondition Parameters in Output Parameter Determination‚Äù (this is exactly what SAP describes for using custom fields in OPD).

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/4aea5a6d73744ea2ae66430230ebcba0.html

       4. Maintain the field for your customers:

    • EDI customers ‚Üí value EDI
    • Everyone else ‚Üí value FORM or leave blank (depending on your design)

Result:
The field on the customer is the single source of truth:

  • Value = EDI-> OPD produces channel EDI
  • Otherwise-> channel FORM (print/email)
  • Cloud-friendly

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Default account assignment, S/4HANA, public cloud edi...
entry.content:
Hello @panagiotism 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Have you had a look at Default account assignment.

The restriction in public cloud is based on factors like Internal Orders not being supported, Default Account Assignment only supporting Cost Centers and Substitution Rules not being able to update WBS fields.

I recommend you assign WBS in the Business process. For example:

  • You can assign PO item to the Project Assignment,
  • Assign your Invoice to WBS in account assignment,
  • Assign your Sales Order to WBS (if its revenue recognition is project-based), etc.

The summary is, public cloud does not support default account assignment because it would bypass the clean-core approach by auto-assigning functions. Therefore, WBS must be entered explicitly in the process because it cannot be automatically derived.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Wrong partners in bill type IG Internal Credit Memo
entry.content:
This mismatch happens because partner determination in the return billing document type (IG) is not aligned with the intercompany return process. SAP standard often defaults to the supplying company‚Äôs customer when the ‚ÄúReturns Item‚Äù flag is used, unless customizing is adjusted.

Please check the below areas

In cross‚Äëcompany STO, each supplying company code‚Äôs vendor is linked to a customer master. For returns, ensure that the receiving company code‚Äôs customer (B) is correctly assigned in customizing for partner determination.

Compare the procedure used in IV vs IG. Often IG is set to derive Sold‚Äëto/Bill‚Äëto/Payer differently. You may need to copy the IV procedure or adjust the access sequence so that B is picked up instead of A.

If ‚ÄúCustomer‚Äù is showing as A, that‚Äôs the root cause. For a return STO, the customer should be B (the one who originally received the goods). This field drives partner determination in the subsequent delivery and billing. Check if the PO type for returns is configured correctly in IMG ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Order ‚Üí Set up STO.

entry.title: Re: Row selection column does not appear in the List Report
entry.content:
@Karthik_Gali

1) You can add as many actions as you want, like the example below:

@UI.lineItem: [
  {
    type:#FOR_ACTION,
    label: 'Change Criticality (#ActionInLineItem)',
    dataAction: 'changeCriticality',
    position: 10
  },
  {
    type:#FOR_ACTION,
    label: 'Second Action',
    dataAction: 'secondAction',
    position: 20
  }
]
LastChangedAt;

2) You can enable multi-selection in the manifest.json file as shown below (no need for a controller extension):

"SalesOrderManageList":{
         "type":"Component",
         "id":"SalesOrderManageList",
         "name":"sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
         "options":{
            "settings":{
               "contextPath":"/SalesOrderManage",
               "controlConfiguration":{
                  "@com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.LineItem":{
                     "tableSettings":{
                        "type":"ResponsiveTable",
                        "selectionMode":"Multi"
                     }
                  }
               }
            }
         }
      }

 https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/#/topic/116b5d82e8c545e2a56e1b51b8b0a9bd

entry.title: Currency Conversion in Multi level / Multi Market Pricebook setup
entry.content:
Hi CPQ Team,
a bit of background. We are working with CPQ Quote 2.0 for a global company. For now the pricing should be maintained via pricebooks. This was fine for the first two Markets we rolled out. 
Now we have markets that are required to quote in various currencies besides the default currency. The standard currency conversion feature does only work if maintain the price books (so copies of the original one) in the Market currency. This currently leads to 100+ pricebooks that need to be maintained, and it's hard to keep track of price changes, ensure all pricebooks are consistent.
Is there a way (possibly via scripting) to change the currency on quote level and keep the Market and pricebook settings?
With that we could get down to a setup where every market would just need to maintain the pricebook in their leading currency.

Appreciate your answers!

Cheers

JD

entry.title: Differentiating QM processes for in-house vs. external procurement under Procurement Type ‚ÄúX‚Äù
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

We are working on an SAP project for a client who wants to use Procurement Type ‚ÄúX‚Äù (both in-house and external procurement) for certain semi-finished and assembly materials.

From the QM side, the client wants to ensure clear differentiation of quality management processes depending on whether the material is produced internally or procured externally.

We are currently analyzing how this can be configured and controlled within SAP ERP.
Some of the main questions we have are:

  1. QM differentiation:

    • How can QM responsibilities, inspection lots, and first article inspections (FAI) be managed separately for in-house vs. externally sourced lots when Procurement Type = ‚ÄúX‚Äù?

    • Are there standard configuration options (e.g., inspection types, source-specific QM data, site-specific fields, or custom enhancements) that allow this distinction?

  2. Governance and master data:

    • If Procurement Type ‚ÄúX‚Äù is used, what governance mechanisms or procedures do you apply to ensure that QM and SCM responsibilities are clearly separated and audit-compliant?

    • Are there cases where separate material numbers are still recommended for QM control reasons?

Any real-world examples, best-practice setups, or configuration hints from projects where Procurement Type ‚ÄúX‚Äù was implemented successfully would be extremely valuable for our analysis.

Thank you very much in advance for your insights!

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Calling an external web service via https using the system certificate store
entry.content:

TLSv1.2:

| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_CCM_8 (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_CCM (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_ARIA_256_GCM_SHA384 (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_CCM_8 (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_CCM (secp256r1) - A
| TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_ARIA_128_GCM_SHA256 (secp256r1) - A

entry.title: Re: Error While Transferring Asset Between Locations in S...
entry.content:
HI @IrfanTech ,

 

The system is telling you that:

  • Source asset (HR01FA30040) has depreciation posted up to a later period,

  • while Target asset (HR04FA60112) has depreciation posted only up to an earlier period.

You cannot perform the transfer/transaction unless the target asset's depreciation is updated to at least the same period as the source asset.

 

  • Source asset HR01FA30040 has depreciation posted up to 2025‚Äì12

  • Target asset HR04FA60112 only has depreciation posted up to 2025‚Äì09

 You must run depreciation for HR04FA60112 through 2025‚Äì12 before posting the transfer/document.

entry.title: SAP TM Transaction SICF Configuration Details.
entry.content:
SAP TM Transaction SICF Configuration Details

Sometimes when Users try to open a Fiori in SAP TM got the error "403 Forbidden". The reason for this error will explain in this blog how to fix it.

Overview

  • In SAP Transportation Management (SAP TM), the SICF (SAP Internet Communication Framework) configuration enables all web-based user interfaces, APIs, and system integrations.
    It ensures that transportation planners, carriers, and connected systems can access TM functionalities through secure web services and Fiori applications.

Prerequisites

  • Required authorizations: SM34, SICF, SM30, SPRO, SU01, STRUST, SE38
  • System requirements: SAP TM 9.1 and subsequent releases, or SAP S/4HANA 1709 and later versions
  • User access levels needed: Administrative privileges for service activation and configuration

Accessing SICF Transaction

  1. Navigate to transaction code SICF in your SAP TM system
  2. Execute the transaction to query the service hierarchy
  3. The initial screen displays the virtual hosts and services tree structure

SICF Configuration for SAP TM

Service Activation Steps

  1. Select the default host or virtual host under which you want to create/activate services
  2. Navigate through the hierarchy tree to locate TM-specific services (/default_host/sap/bc/webdynpro/scmtms)
  3. Right-click on services and choose "Activate Service" to enable them

After activated it you also can execute a Test to ensure the error is not appearing.

A popup will appear to open the Fiori:

 

Key TM Services in SICF

Service Name

Path

Purpose

WebDynpro TM Interfaces

/default_host/sap/bc/webdynpro/scmtms

All TM WebDynpro User Interfaces

UI5 Services

/default_host/sap/public/bc/ui5_ui5

Freight Order Utilization, Transportation Cockpit

GANTT Chart Services

/default_host/sap/bc/bsp/gntlb, /default_host/sap/bc/bsp/scmtms

Transportation Cockpit GANTT Chart

File Upload Services

/default_host/sap/public/bc/ui5_ui5/ILMRWC

Drag & Drop file attachments

APC Services

/default_host/sap/bc/apc/sap/fpm_apc

ABAP Push Channel for TM 9.5+

REST TRP Service

/sap/bc/rest_trp

TM service for Transportation Resource Planning


Service Configuration Parameters

HTTP Settings

  • Configure virtual hosts based on your system landscape requirements
  • Set appropriate port settings for HTTP/HTTPS communication
  • Enable SSL configuration for secure data transmission

Authentication Settings

  • Configure client number in the Logon Data tab for TM-specific services
  • Set up handler classes (e.g., /TRP/CL_REST_APP for REST services)
  • Assign appropriate user credentials for service access

Testing and Validation

  1. After service activation, clear cache globally and locally through transaction SMICM
  2. Navigate to Menu ‚Üí Goto ‚Üí Http Plugin ‚Üí Server cache ‚Üí Invalidate locally and globally
  3. Test service accessibility through web browser or integration testing tools
  4. Verify proper authentication and data exchange

Support documentation for this topic

2614758 - Important SICF services in SAP Transportation Management - SAP for Me

2807334 - Web Dynpro SICF nodes for Transportation Management - SAP for Me

Creating and Activating ICF Service | SAP Help Portal

Configuration of SAP Transportation Management | SAP Help Portal

3660702 - 403 forbidden error when accessing "Create Transportation Duration Determination Profile" in SAP S/4HANA 2023 - SAP for Me

2834523 - Troubleshooting 500 Internal Server Error when opening any SAP TM UI screen - SAP for Me

Hope this support you.!

Kind regards

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Need To Add a Custom Field into Import Supplier Invoices
entry.content:
I attempted to use the Custom Fields and Logic (CFL) app to enable and extend the required UI for adding a custom field ‚Äì Special G/L Indicator (UMSKZ) to the Import Supplier Invoices template. However, after performing the configuration and downloading the updated template, the custom field does not appear, even after unhiding all available columns.

Environment Details

  • System: SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud (Standard Application)

  • Application: Import Supplier Invoices (Fiori App)

  • Extension Tool: Custom Fields and Logic (CFL)

  • Custom Field: Special G/L Indicator (UMSKZ)

Actions Performed

  1. Created the custom field Special G/L Indicator (UMSKZ) in the CFL app and published it successfully.

  2. Enabled the field for the relevant Business Context associated with Supplier Invoices.

  3. Activated the field for the respective UI and OData Service.

  4. Verified successful activation and publishing in CFL.

  5. Downloaded the updated Import Supplier Invoices template from the Fiori application.

  6. Unhid all available columns in the Excel template to check for the new field.

Current Behavior

The Special G/L Indicator (UMSKZ) field does not appear in the Import Supplier Invoices template, even though it has been correctly created, enabled, and published in CFL.

Expected Behavior

The Special G/L Indicator (UMSKZ) custom field should be visible in the Import Supplier Invoices template once enabled through CFL and the template is regenerated.

Request for Assistance

Kindly advise on the following:

  • Does the Import Supplier Invoices standard application in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud support CFL-based custom fields in the import template?

  • Are there any additional configurations or extension points required to make the custom field visible in the import template (e.g., via adaptation, custom communication scenario, or OData extension)?

  • Are there any known limitations or SAP Notes related to the non-reflection of CFL custom fields (such as UMSKZ) in the Supplier Invoice Import template?

entry.title: Configuring a depreciation key with different formulas per year and after technical improvement
entry.content:
Subject: Need help configuring a custom depreciation key with different formulas per year and after technical improvement by standard SAP.

Hi SAP Community,

I need to configure a rather specific depreciation key for a customer, and I‚Äôd like to ask for your advice.

The requested logic is as follows:

  • Depreciation amount in the first year:
    Depreciation amount in the first year = Acquisition value / Depreciation coefficient for the first year,

  • Depreciation amount in the following years:
    Depreciation amount in the next years = (2 * Net book value) / (Depreciation coefficient for next years - Already depreciated periods)

  • Depreciation amount after a technical improvement:
    Depreciation amount after technical improvement= (2 * Net book value) / (Depreciation coefficient after technical improvement - Already depreciated periods after certain technical improvement)

So basically, we have three different formulas:

  1. One for the first year,

  2. Another one from the second year onward,

  3. And a third one that should apply starting from the moment a technical improvement (capitalization) occurs.

Do you have any idea how this could be configured in SAP?
Is it possible to handle all three cases within a single depreciation key, or would it require multiple keys or a BAdI implementation?

entry.title: Re: Output Determination for the Maintenance Notification...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Role in Output Parameter Determination for maintenance notifications and orders should be aligned with the business partner function that represents the receiver of the output (for example, Employee Responsible, Planner Group, or Customer depending on the process). For maintenance orders, SAP standard practice is to use the Business Partner linked to the order (such as the technical object‚Äôs customer or the responsible person). If the role is not correctly defined, the system cannot automatically trigger outputs when the notification reaches ‚ÄúCompleted.‚Äù

Why the Role matters is because the Role field in Output Parameter Determination specifies who the output is sent to. If left blank or incorrectly set, the system cannot resolve the recipient, so automatic output fails even though manual generation works. In maintenance notifications/orders, typical roles include:

  • Business Partner (Customer) ‚Üí when external communication is required.
  • Employee Responsible / Planner Group ‚Üí for internal job cards or completion reports.
  • Supplier ‚Üí in procurement‚Äërelated outputs.

To summarize, the missing piece is the correct Role definition in Output Parameter Determination. Standard practice is to align the role with the business partner function present in the notification/order (Employee Responsible, Planner Group, or Customer). Once this is set, automatic output generation will trigger as expected.

entry.title: MM43 - restriction of finance view permerchandise categories without restricting material master dat
entry.content:
Dear community,

I am seeking your help as I have a customer requirement to access MM43 as follows:
- Population 1: Shouldn't have access to finance view (Standard price & CCR) for any materia, but should keep access to basic data for all materials
- Population 2: Should have access to finance view (Standard price & CCR) for finished products only, but should keep access to basic data for all materials
- Population 3: Should have access to finance view (Standard price & CCR) for components only, but should keep access to basic data for all materials

I understand that restricting the finance view implies restricting authorizations in field BEGRU of M_MATE_MAR auth object. But the issue is that it will impact access to basic master data too.

For example for population 2, if we restrict BEGRU field to include finished products only, this population will lose access to basic data of other merchandise categories. Which cannot be accepted.

Would you have any recommendation (or solution) to apply the customer requirements?

Thank you very much

entry.title: Review Booklets and Multidimensional Analysis Apps: What you need to know about Accessibility?
entry.content:
Introduction 

Review Booklets and Multidimensional Analysis Applications have made significant progress towards modernizing the reporting capabilities in S/4HANA. This greatly improves the ability of business user to monitor your business and obtain business insights within embedded analytics. Those capabilities have now matured to the point where they are ready for mainstream consumption. In this blog we would like to focus on important aspects of usability and accessibility.

Please remember the previous blogs and documentation regarding those reporting apps from earlier releases:

- www.help.sap.com

- Multidimensional Analysis a Stepstone to modern Reporting in S/4HANA 

Those reporting apps have become more and more insightful, deliver standard reporting out-of the box with immediate real-time access to data, within the known Fiori user experience, and without additional installations or efforts. 

Here is a short overview of the most important features:

Figure 1: Use Cases

Important features are:

  • guided business pages and layouts, optimized for typical business questions
  • generic pivoting and drill-down in layout side panel
  • filtering on booklet and page level
  • contextual navigation using intent-based navigation
  • cell-based commenting and page comments
  • AI assisted Business insights
  • collaboration on business pages in teams and on comments using notifications
  • copy, create and adapt booklets within key user extensibility or
  • create new booklets as customer developer using embedded steampunk

The Accessibility Approach:

An important step towards maturity is the question: How can advanced reporting meet the standards of accessibility?
Accessibility needs to ensure that everyone can effectively use and interact with complex multidimensional analytical tasks, regardless of whether they have disabilities or not. Here are some important aspects to consider:

  1. Intuitive Interface Design including simple and consistent layout, easy to understand with intuitive navigation
    - Simplicity in "Accessibility and Fullscreen mode"
    - Simple Screen Titles, Headings and accessible alternatives
  2. Visual Perception and Readability
    - Text Resizing
    - Color and Contrast Setting,
    - Responsive Design,
  3. Key Board Navigation
    - Consistent navigation and Context menus
    - Key board focus,  Group Skipping, etc.
  4. Assistive Tool Support  and Screen Reader

Those topics will be illustrated and explained in this blog.
Please note that there are many usability features that are very useful for everyone.

Intuitive User Interface and Accessibility/Fullscreen Mode

A typical review booklet combines multiple pages prepared to answer the most typical business question in a certain area.

The information is offered through a user-Interface consisting of a "Filter Bar", multiple "Business Pages", "Combo Boxes", "Table/Grid with Context Menus" and "Side Panels" offering different features and capabilities:

Figure 2: User Interface Elements

A typical example might look like the screen below.
For users with disabilities or impairments, it might be challenging to access the different controls and interact with the many features, ranging from filtering and changing the layout to advanced pivoting. 


Figure 3: From Review Booklet to full-screen mode

Nevertheless "Review Booklets" and "Multidimensional Applications" are designed with accessibility and usability in mind.

To simplify the screen,  we offer a full screen mode, which also serves as an accessibility mode. See Figure 3.
Each feature is available through an accessible alternative within the context menu. See more details in the chapter key board navigation and figure 6.

Figure 4: Agenda View in full-screen mode
In full-screen mode you work and explore the current page, but you can easily access all pages via a simple agenda view,  as shown in Figure 4.

Visual Perception and Readability

This allows you to zoom into the details and ensure that all the details are easy to read.
Combined with theming (for example the High Contrast Black Theme)  and responsive design, the readability can be increased dramatically. 
 

Figure 5: High Contrast Black Horizon Theme

Key Board Navigation

Keyboard navigation is a convenient way to move the focus in your application without using the mouse. By using Tab and Shift Tab you can move the focus to the next element on the screen. Group Skipping -  F6 and Shift F6 allows you to quickly jump between groups of elements such as the filter bar, table or side panel.

Figure 6: Opening context menu to access all features

As already mentioned before, the most important feature is to launch the context menu using Ctrl Shift F10.

 This gives you easy access to all available feature via an accessible path

  • the layout can be changed by
    • adding, removing or moving dimensions to rows and columns
    • Hierarchy handling or
    • Filtering
  • in addition you can open accessible a side panels to work on 
    • page filters
    • comments
    • export to Excel and PDF
  • or use contextual navigation

Assistive Tool Support  and Screen Reader

Assistive tool support and screen readers are crucial for visually impaired individuals to access digital content. The recommended screen reader is JAWS (Job Access With Speech), which reads the content on the screen aloud, allowing users to navigate and interact with their computers using text-to-speech technology. JAWS can describe icons, menus, and other screen elements, making it easier for people with visual impairments to use applications and websites independently.

Especially for screen reader use cases, it is very important that every cell contains the full information.
Merged cells are cause trouble because relevant information gets lost.
This can be fixed by showing the content of merged cells as shown in the screenshot below.

Figure 7: Display the content of merged cells

In addition, we can also move the currency into the related amount cell using the formatting side panel.
By default the currency is typically shown in the column header, which also causes issues in screen reader use cases.

Figure 8: How to add currency or Unit to Data Cells

Ressources:
Accessibilty Features in Review Booklets
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/6b356c79dea443c4bbeeaf0865e04207/e14ea59510d54bf1979ae7fc11a5cda4.html

entry.title: Failure in Hana integration with SAP DM in Classification Assignment Download messages.
entry.content:
Dear Colleagues,
I hope you are all well.

I am facing a problem integrating Material Master Data from our SAP system (S/4HANA) to SAP Digital Manufacturing (DM), and I would like to know if anyone in the community has encountered or has knowledge about this situation.

The Problem:
When executing the DRFOUT transaction to replicate multiple materials to Digital Manufacturing, the observed behavior is as follows:
‚Ä¢ Material Master Data (MATMAS) messages are sent and processed correctly in Digital Manufacturing.
‚Ä¢ However, Classification Assignment Download messages for these materials are not being sent or downloaded correctly in their entirety.

‚Ä¢ Some classification assignment messages are missing or not being generated/sent to DM, resulting in incomplete or missing classification data for some of the materials in the target system.

My Questions:
1. Has anyone encountered a similar scenario where classification messages are not reliably sent when replicating multiple materials via DRFOUT?
2. Is there any SAP Note or specific setting in DRFOUT or Customizing that might be limiting the sending of these secondary messages when the volume of materials is high?

3. What would be the recommended path to debug/trace the failure in generating/sending the Classification Assignment message (IDoc or service) after the MATMAS has been generated?

Any insight, tip, or documentation reference would be extremely helpful.

Thank you immensely for your attention and collaboration.

Sincerely,
